title: 107_s1828
content: The Act titled "Federal Prosecutors Retirement Benefit Equity Act of 2001" includes federal prosecutors in the definition of a law enforcement officer. The Act "Federal Prosecutors Retirement Benefit Equity Act of 2001" amends the Civil Service Retirement System to include federal prosecutors as defined by the Act. The "Federal Prosecutors Retirement Benefit Equity Act of 2001" amends the Federal Employees' Retirement System to include federal prosecutors as defined by the Act. The "Federal Prosecutors Retirement Benefit Equity Act of 2001" includes federal prosecutors as defined by the Act, allowing them to be appointed as assistant United States attorneys or attorneys employed by the Department of Justice designated by the Attorney General of the United States. Certain provisions of law related to original appointments and mandatory separation remain unchanged. The amendments made by the "Federal Prosecutors Retirement Benefit Equity Act of 2001" will take effect on the first day of the first applicable pay period beginning on or after 120 days after the date of enactment of the Act. SEC. 3. PROVISIONS RELATING TO INCUMBENTS. In this section, a Federal prosecutor is defined as an assistant United States attorney or an attorney designated by the Attorney General. An incumbent is defined as an individual serving as a Federal prosecutor on the effective date of this section. The Attorney General must make any designations of attorneys before the effective date and submit them to the Office of Personnel Management. The Department of Justice must provide notice to incumbents regarding their election rights under the Act and the consequences of making a timely election. Incumbents have the option to elect to be treated according to the Act's amendments or as if the Act had never been enacted. Under the Act, incumbents must make a timely election to be treated according to the amendments or as if the Act had never been enacted. Failure to elect on time is treated as a late election. The election must be made within 120 days of receiving notice or upon separation from service. Retroactive effect applies to all service performed by an incumbent who elects the option under subsection (d)(1)(A). All service performed by an individual as a Federal prosecutor shall be treated according to applicable provisions of title 5, United States Code, with retroactive effect for those who elect the option under subsection (d)(1)(A). Individuals can contribute to the Civil Service Retirement and Disability Fund for prior service by making up the difference between actual and required contributions if they elect to do so under subsection (d)(1)(A). Individuals can contribute to the Civil Service Retirement and Disability Fund for prior service by making up the difference between actual and required contributions if they elect to do so under subsection (d)(1)(A). If the full amount is not paid, prior service remains creditable but the resulting annuity is reduced to make up the unpaid amount. "Prior service" refers to service performed before retirement deductions begin according to the election. If an incumbent elects under subsection (d)(1)(A), the Department of Justice will remit the required amount for prior service contributions to the Civil Service Retirement and Disability Fund. This amount is the additional Government contributions that would have been required if the amendments were in effect. Contributions are to be made ratably. Government contributions for incumbents will be made by the Department of Justice ratably over a 10-year period. The Office of Personnel Management will establish regulations for this Act, including interest determination on specified amounts. This section will be effective 120 days after the Act's enactment. SEC. 4. DEPARTMENT OF JUSTICE ADMINISTRATIVE ACTIONS. The term "Federal prosecutor" is defined in this section, and the Attorney General must consult with the Office of Personnel Management to create regulations for designating Federal prosecutors who are not assistant United States attorneys within 120 days of the Act's enactment. These regulations ensure that designated attorneys have similar responsibilities to assistant United States attorneys. The Attorney General has the discretion to designate any Federal prosecutor who is not an assistant United States attorney. This includes representation before grand juries, trials, appeals, and related court proceedings.
